content: The Earth orbits the Sun at an average distance of about 93 million miles (150 million kilometers).
Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius (212 degrees Fahrenheit) at sea level under standard atmospheric pressure.
The human body contains approximately 37.2 trillion cells, according to recent scientific estimates.
Mount Everest is the tallest mountain on Earth, with its peak reaching 8,849 meters (29,032 feet) above sea level.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792,458 meters per second.
The Amazon rainforest produces approximately 20% of the world's oxygen supply.
DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) contains the genetic instructions used in the development and functioning of all known living organisms.
The Great Wall of China is over 13,000 miles (21,000 kilometers) long when including all of its branches.
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy stored in glucose.
The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth, covering more than 63 million square miles.
Albert Einstein developed the theory of relativity in the early 20th century, revolutionizing physics.
The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons that communicate through synapses.
Gold has the chemical symbol Au, derived from the Latin word aurum.
The Mona Lisa was painted by Leonardo da Vinci in the early 16th century and is housed in the Louvre Museum.
Sound travels faster through water than through air, at approximately 1,480 meters per second in water.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world, covering approximately 9 million square kilometers.
Honey never spoils due to its low moisture content and acidic pH, making it a natural preservative.
The human heart beats approximately 100,000 times per day, pumping about 2,000 gallons of blood.
Shakespeare wrote 37 plays and 154 sonnets during his lifetime in the late 16th and early 17th centuries.
Dinosaurs went extinct approximately 65 million years ago, likely due to an asteroid impact.
The planet Jupiter has at least 79 known moons, with the four largest being Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.
Penicillin was discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928, marking the beginning of modern antibiotics.
The Pythagorean theorem states that in a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of the other two sides.
Coffee is one of the most traded commodities in the world, with over 400 billion cups consumed annually.
The first computer programmer was Ada Lovelace, who wrote the first algorithm for Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine.
Bees perform a waggle dance to communicate the location of food sources to other members of their hive.
The Declaration of Independence was signed on July 4, 1776, marking the birth of the United States of America.
Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system, with surface temperatures reaching 900 degrees Fahrenheit.
The human eye can distinguish approximately 10 million different colors.
The periodic table was first published by Dmitri Mendeleev in 1869, organizing elements by atomic weight.
Antarctica contains approximately 90% of the world's ice and 70% of its fresh water.
The speed of sound in air at sea level is approximately 343 meters per second or 767 miles per hour.
Sharks have existed for over 400 million years, making them older than trees.
The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1889 and stands 324 meters (1,063 feet) tall including its antenna.
Red blood cells live for approximately 120 days before being replaced by new ones.
The Amazon River is the second-longest river in the world, stretching approximately 6,400 kilometers.
Fingerprints are unique to each individual and remain unchanged throughout a person's lifetime.
The Gutenberg printing press, invented around 1440, revolutionized the spread of knowledge in Europe.
Octopuses have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, while the third pumps it to the rest of the body.
The longest recorded flight of a chicken is 13 seconds, covering a distance of 301.5 feet.
Black holes have gravitational fields so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape once it crosses the event horizon.
The human skeleton is made up of 206 bones in adults, though babies are born with approximately 270.
The Dead Sea is the lowest point on Earth's surface, located 430 meters below sea level.
Bamboo is the fastest-growing plant on Earth, with some species growing up to 91 centimeters in a single day.
The Apollo 11 mission successfully landed humans on the Moon on July 20, 1969.
Antibiotics are ineffective against viral infections because they specifically target bacterial cell structures.
The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States, dedicated on October 28, 1886.
Mitochondria are known as the powerhouses of the cell because they generate most of the cell's ATP energy.
The largest living organism on Earth is a honey fungus in Oregon's Blue Mountains, covering 2,385 acres.
The International Space Station orbits Earth at an average altitude of 408 kilometers and travels at 28,000 kilometers per hour.
